captions.text:
Hi guys, I'm Laura Vitale and on this episode
of Laura in the Kitchen, I want to share with

you my take - remember, it's not by any means
the traditional way to do this - but this
is my take on a veggie lo mein.

I had such a great response from my beef and
broccoli stir fry that I just feel more confident

to share my take on different kinds of things,
specifically take out food that so many of

us love, and if you know anything about me,
you know that I live in a very small town,

and sometimes it can be quite difficult to
get takeout so when we can, we like to make
it at home!

And my veggie lo mein is so good, so easy,
you can put any veggies you want in it, this
just happens to be my go-to, but you do you.

Whatever you've got on hand, whatever you
like, that's what you use.

Use this as an inspiration to raid your fridge
and get to cooking.

The ingredients you'll need are very few,
I'm starting off with some carrots that I've

just sliced into little pieces, I've got the
onions, ginger, a mixture of mushrooms, I've

got shiitake and cremini, these are some Chinese
egg noodles, I've also got some Bok Cgoy that

I've sliced up, I've got some bean sprouts
here, I've got a little bit of sugar, oyster

sauce, soy sauce and some scallions (green
onions).

What I have is a pot with some boiling water
coming up to a boil for my noodles, and I'm

going to get started right away. I have a
really big skillet here, I don't have a wok,

but the biggest skillet you have is what you
should use.

And I've got a little bit of vegetable oil
in there and I'm going to add my carrots,

onions, mushrooms, and ginger and this is
on high heat, as hot as it will go.

Add that in, and saute this for about two
minutes, you really don't want to go any further

than that, in total, this should cook for
about four or five minutes, so it's also really
quick cooking, which I love.

And I have my skillet on the back burner because
it's the hottest burner of the two. And I'm

just going to let this cook for two minutes
and then we'll proceed.

This looks awesome, okay, it's been two minutes
I'm going to add my noodles to the boiling

water, cook them for two minutes and then
we'll meet back here and we'll put the whole
thing together.

Okay, I only cooked my noodles for two minutes,
now the package instructions says three to

four minutes but I only cook them for about
two minutes and twenty seconds or so because

I'm going to cook it together with the sauce
and stuff for just another minute and I don't
want them to be over cooked.

Going to just move that back here, going to
add my Bok Choy, I'm also going to add my

soy, Oyster Sauce, and sugar just a little
bit of sugar just to kind of balance everything

out. I like to mix them together first just
for a quick second.
Mix like so.
Pour all of this over.
I love that sound!

Okay, like two minutes and this is done, you
just want to make sure that that Bok Choy

wilts a bit and that that sauce coats everything
really nicely.
Throwing in my sprouts at the last minute.

Get those in, warm them up, and the Bok Choy
has only been in for a minute, at the last

minute I like to add in my sprouts, and then
everything cooks together for one more minute
and then it's done!
You will be ready to serve!
Turning that off.
Stirring in some scallions.
Smells phenomenal in here!

You can use baby Bok Choy, I can't - it's
hard for me to find it in my local grocery

store so I just take regular Bok Choy and
just slice it up nice and thick because I
don't like it to be too mushy.

Serve myself a modest portion before dinner
because that's just how I roll my friends.

And you could put snap peas in here, goodness,
you could put anything your heart desires
in here.
Chop sticks.

Because contrary to many beliefs, I can get
quite fancy.
Haha!
Love.
Ah, this smells like, like take out!

But better, because I know exactly what's
in it and, oh goodness, like I can just play
around with whatever my heart desires.
It's going to be way too much.
Give me a second.
Mmm!
That is the bomb diggiddy!
Hot!
It's amazing!
Really hot though!

Really delicious, really simple, the texture
of the veggies is fantastic, I don't like

to take them too far as far as a little bit
of crunch.
Fabulous!

Okay, go to LauraintheKitchen.com to get the
written recipe, I hope you have enjoyed spending

time with me, leave me your requests down
below for take out videos, for your favorite

takeout dishes you want me to do here on Laura
in the Kitchen because, as you can see, It's
so easy!

It takes absolutely no time and I would love
to hear from you what some of your favorites

are so I can recreate them for you, so that
you can make them in the comfort of your very
own home!

LauraintheKitchen.com has the recipe waiting
for you, hope you've enjoyed spending time
with me and I'll see you next time!
Bye!

title: Homemade Vegetable Lo Mein Recipe - Laura Vitale - Laura in the Kitchen Episode 878

comments.author: Alishia Zafar

comments.text:
Laura, Lovely Vegetable Lo Mein recipe. May I suggest as an alternate prep, 
you try the following; Stir fry the veggies as usual first. Remove from 
pan. Briefly saute the fresh minced ginger adding a minced fresh clove of 
garlic. Incorporate the veggies and noodles. Add additionally to your sauce 
mixture, half a teaspoon of Asian Sesame oil,and 1-2 teaspoons of Dry 
Sherry(very close to Chinese Shao Xing wine and what many Chinese 
restaurants use) along with the Oyster sauce and sugar. Watching so many of 
your superb Youtube cooking videos,I know your family doesnt add garlic to 
many sauces and dishes. Our family loves garlic,but of course,it's personal 
preference. Minced garlic,ginger,a splash of sherry/wine, is traditional in 
many regional Chinese noodle stirfrys. Give it a try.
Thank you for being so generous with your family's recipes and all your 
videos. All the best to you and your family. Congratulations on your new 
show. Buon Appetito!
P.S. My Sicilian Nonna and Mom used to make "Babaluci", snails in a tomato 
sauce, Fra Diavolo style, in Brooklyn many years ago. Cannot seem to find 
those snails anymore. Batter dipped,golden fried zucchini flowers were also 
a special treat. Family food memories seem to resonate the strongest.﻿
